lines.text: Most people know nothing about themselves. Nothing. Their own real personality is a complete stranger to them. Now, what I'm trying to do is to introduce you to your inner-self. I want you to get acquainted with yourself. Wouldn't you like to meet you? Don't you want to get to know yourself?
No. You see, I'm a little shy.
Now, I don't want to cause any trouble. But cold facts are cold facts! If Mr. and Mrs. Cooper come, that big, awful looking Mrs. Cooper, he shaves.
And if he has dinner alone with his wife, he doesn't shave!
And if anybody should shave, it's Mrs. Cooper!
And I spent three-and-a-half hours today at Elizabeth Arden's, but I don't rate a shave.
I was doing some secretarial work for Mr. Baker.
Oh, secretary's work on Saturday night?
Oh, well, eh, I-I'm a notary public too.
Oh, I see. And you brought your seal?
Oh, yes!
A-ha, a trained seal.
There's nothing wrong with your marriage. You just have to resell it once in awhile.
Dr. Vengard. I repeat it, Dr. Vengard is the man for you.
Don't let's go into that again. I will not be psycho-analyzed.
Oh, now, Jill. That's a very middle-class attitude.
I'm a perfectly normal woman.
Well, that's sounds awfully dull.
My dear you musn't say that about yourself - not even in fun!
Egészségedre!
Egészségedre?
[looks around the table at the other guests; then, indicating Jill]
Egészségedre!
Miss Aikens, we want a woman's point of view on a certain situation. Now, Mr. Baker has a friend and he's in trouble...
Oh, Mr. Baker!

[Shushing Larry]
Now, Mr. Baker has nothing whatever to do with it. Let's call the friend Mr. Brown. Now, Mr. Brown has a wife... Mr. & Mrs. Brown have been married for, uh, how long?
Well, say six years. They live in Toledo.
Six years in Toledo. That's bad.
All right then, let's say New York. Now Mr. Brown is worried about his marriage. Things are not going along as well as they used to.
What kind of a man IS this Mr. Brown?
Very nice...
Is he attractive?
Very attractive.
[to Larry]
Don't you think so?
Yes.
And yet she's complaining.
Well, she's drifting away from him.
Yes, and he wants to get things back on the old basis.
Who doesn't?
Yes.
[clears throat]
Now, Miss Aikens, as a woman, I'm asking you, what is the right approach?
Well, I should say a mink coat would do the trick.
She has a mink coat.
Then what's she complaining about?
[the men are exasperated, and Jones dismisses Miss Aikens from the conversation]
Just a moment. Now look here. Mrs. Brown is interested in another man.

Oh... If there aren't any witnesses she's going to deny it... But I'm afraid I'm not the right person to give you any advice. I probably have too much sympathy for Mr. Brown, and not enough patience with Mrs. Brown. We get cases like that every day. The wife is bored; marriage is just a habit. But on the other hand, she accepts everything her husband gives her. I think she ought to be kicked out. Do I sound old-fashioned?
No, we'll let you know, Miss Aikens.
Well anyway, I think Mr. Brown's a pretty swell guy. I've always thought so.
[Miss Aikens leaves the room]
...She certainly had a couple of interesting angles.
I didn't notice them.
[repeated line]
I'm not going to fight.
[repeated line]
Phooey!
You smoke yourself?
Yes.

[a pause]
You, eh, haven't got a cigarette, eh?
Yes.
[she takes her cigarette case from her handbag and offers it to him]
Haven't any without tips?

Men have been rightly called the Masters of the World. Men have subdued the wild animals. Men have penetrated deep into the jungle, and have been able to look at the Moon and the planets. But there is still one place on Earth where no man has ever set foot nor has been even permitted to glimpse.
the "Ladies Lounge" door]
It's difficult to show you the symptoms at the moment, because - it comes and it goes.
Oh, it comes and - it goes.
Yes. It's so unfortunate. It's always the same whenever I see a doctor. When - when I come, it goes. And when I go, it comes.
Mrs. Baker, whatever comes and whatever goes, there's no denying it worries you a lot. So, please drop all your inhibitions, release your inner-self, and speak freely. What comes and what goes?
Hiccups!
Doctor, please believe me, there's nothing wrong with my marriage. You could go through all Park Avenue and you wouldn't find a happier couple.
Well, I'm sorry, but it's my duty to explore every avenue, especially Park Avenue.
After all, husbands expect their wives to keep their figures.
A gargle. That's the bugle call of marriage. Gargle is reveille, snore is taps.
I've always heard that the ideal marriage should be something of a mystery. That your husband should remain a kind of stranger to you. Someone whose acquaintance you'd like to renew every day.
Ah, good grief!
he's a Hungarian. As a matter of fact, they're all Hungarians. So, so let's give the dinner a kind of - Hungarian touch, heh?
Now look, Larry...
Oh, now listen, darling, I didn't expect you to behave like a gypsy. But, let's hire a Hungarian cook and make him a wonderful goulash!
Success in business is fifty per cent hard work and fifty per cent the right cigar.
Just a habit, isn't it?
Yes, if you want to call it that.
Like scratching your head or patting your dog. Would you do it to some other woman?
Well, I don't know. I never tried.
But, you do it to me.
Well, you're my wife.
And that gives you the right to poke me in the stomach whenever you want, heh?
Larry, please don't keeks me anymore.
Let me warn you that I say what I think. I'm a complete individualist.
Really?
I'm against Communism, Capitalism, Fascism, Nazism. I'm against everything and everybody. I hate my fellow man and he hates me.
It sounds rather amusing.
So, I amuse you? I'm a clown, eh? Pagliacci!
What's wrong with you?

[Defensively]
Nothing.
Why are you here? You don't go to a psycho-analyst to have tooth filled?
I hate to bother you again; but, eh - what does one have to do to be happy?
That's almost great.
Who painted it?
A woman. No man could be so malicious.
You are a puzzle, Mr. Alexander Sebastian.
And don't you try to solve me, Mrs. Happy Baker.
This vase insults me. It's ugly. Let's put it away.
These Hungarians are certainly funny people.
He's not a piano player, he's a pianist.
You should know better, musicians and mattresses don't mix!
Listen, how long is a sonata?
The only one I ever heard lasted three cigars.

[Mr. Baker sneaks up behind Mrs. Baker and puts his hands over her eyes]
Oh, nice surprise, eh! Ha-ha-ha. Hello, my genius. Ha-ha. Who are you going to be this evening? Come, tell your little cadenza! Are you - Mozart? Playful, tender? Or, are you the thundering Beethoven? Strong, fiery, unyielding! Come, darling. Tell your little cade - -
[Turns around, realizes it is her husband, and faints]
If you ever should run into one of her bad moods and you want to snap her right out if it, there's only one way to do it.
What's that?
Just - keeks her.
Keeks her? How do you do that?
Just
[pokes Sebastian in the stomach]
It's okay. It's quick and painless.
Very white of you, Baker.
Thanks, Sebastian.
Ho-ho-ho. Am I going to be difficult! I'm gonna be the mad dog of 685 Park Avenue. Heil Baker!
[Makes a Nazi salute]
So, you can hit a man, but you don't dare strike a woman. You, coward, you!
How dare you say that about my beloved mother!
Your beloved mother - pooh!
Who are you to pooh my mother?

[Repeated line]
You cheap, second-rate, insurance peddler!
He had to get drunk to do it.
How is everything going?
Oh, not so well sir. I came to ask if in your future plans you'd have any use for me?
Have you left Miss Baker?
Yes sir, I had to - on account of that - musical gentleman. In fact, we all left, except Emma. But, then she fortunately is quite deaf.
Very exciting - being transferred from the business world into the world of art. Nothing but Bach and Tchaikovsky!
I love to make him angry. He turns into a - big - Grizzly bear!
I only hope poor Larry has as good a time as I.
Well, when I saw him at the Monte Carlo...
Oh, yes, I suppose that was another one of those dull, business evenings. Was it a large party?
No, I'd say she was about your size.
There's no use pretending - I'm defeated.
A little bit softer, please.
